occurrences.line_text: Did feele his pulse, she knew their staied still
And feeling by his pulses beating rife,
Emongst the pumy stones, and made a sowne,
Emongst the pumy stones, which seemd to plaine
To punish: yet it better first I thought,
He cast to punish for his hainous fault;
So doth he punish her and eke himselfe torment.
Are bound for to reuenge, and punish if they may.
Which punish wicked men, that walke amisse:
To punish those, that doe deserue the same;
That we may it auenge, and punish him with speed?
Their cruelty, and him to punish more,
Would for it selfe redresse, and punish such despights.
He sorely punished with heauie payne;
In which ten thousand sorts of punishment
The greater sin, the greater punishment:
The Britons, for their sinnes dew punishment,
She gan for me deuise a grieuous punishment.
And threatned him with force & punishment extreme.
And with thy punishment his penance shalt supply.
That was the author of her punishment;
It's punishment enough, that all his shame doe see.
Vpon him did inflict this punishment.
Inflicting on her selfe his punishment.
Then Zele began to vrge her punishment,
His groning soule vnto her place of punishment.
And eke Grantortoes worthy punishment.
On whom he did inflict most grieuous punishment.
Fayre Mirabellaes punishment
Till that he him deliuered to his punishment.
The picture of his punishment might see,
As if it them should grieue to see his punishment.
Or paines in loue, or punishments in hell;
And Pupill fit for such a Tutours hand.
Whiles deadly fit thy pupill doth dismay;
Vsurpt the crowne, during their pupillage;
Gotten by spoyle, then purchaced aright.
Which he had got abroad by purchase criminall.
That shall I shortly purchase to your hond:
That could her purchase with his liues aduentur'd gage.
And purchase honour in his friends behalue,
Forgoe the purchase of my gotten pray,
And purchase me some place amongst the best.
To purchase a licentious libertie.
Both goodly meede of him it purchase may,
And purchase it to vs with speare and shield:
Was his owne purchase and his onely prize,
And purchased this peerelesse beauties spoile,
And glorious spoiles, purchast in perilous fight:
To whom he did diuide part of his purchast spoile.
And purchast all the countrey lying ny
Should as his purchast prize with him conuay
Which brought that Damzell, as his purchast pray;
Purchast through lawlesse powre and tortious wrong
And with the greatest purchast greatest grace:
So pure and innocent, as that same lambe,
And drizling teares did shed for pure affection.
Into a pure vermillion now are dyde:
To runne her timely race, whilst Phoebus pure
Then hunt the steps of pure vnspotted Maid:
But all of Diamond perfect pure and cleene
Wherein were closd few drops of liquor pure,
And pure vnspotted life: so well they say
As they in pure vermilion had beene dide,
For it is chast and pure, as purest snow,
Then taking Congï¿½ fÂ© of that virgin pure,
With faire vermilion or pure Castory.
So pure and shiny, that the siluer flood
That like pure Orient perles adowne it trild,
For she was pure from blame of sinfull blot,
Was all abasht, and her pure yuory
As for pure chastitie and vertue rare,
Pure and vnspotted from all loathly crime,
In blessed Nectar, and pure Pleasures well,
Some headed with sad lead, some with pure gold;
But with pure gold it all was ouerlayd,
Pure in aspect, and like to christall glasse,
So pure the mettall was, and well refynd,
In whose pure minde, as in a mirrour sheene
Most perfect pure, and guiltlesse innocent
That like two Orient pearles, did purely shyne
That purest skye with brightnesse they dismaid:
For it is chast and pure, as purest snow,
At the well head the purest streames arise:
And ouer all, of purest gold was spred,
Which all of purest bullion framed were,
Was purest snow in massie mould congeald,
Purfled with gold and pearle of rich assay,
Purfled vpon with many a folded plight,
When morning altars purgd with enemies life,
Not purg'd nor heald, behind remained still,
His chosen people purg'd from sinfull guilt,
Might not be purgd with water nor with bath;
I meant to purge both with a third mischiefe,
To purge away the guilt of sinfull crime:
Vnited all his powres to purge himselfe from blame.
Purged from drugs of foule intemperance:
Of which some were rude owre, not purifide
The whiles my hands I washt in puritie,
Purloynd both steed and speare, and ran away full light.
Yet was that all but painted, and purloynd,
Had it purloyned for his maister bad:)
His horse purloyned was by subtill traine:
Had spred her purple robe through deawy aire,
And streames of purple bloud new dies the verdant fields.
As faire Aurora in her purple pall,
He gaue her gold and purple pall to weare,
Enforst her purple beast with all her might
And robd of royall robes, and purple pall,
And the cleane waues with purple gore did ray;
Soone as the morrow faire with purple beames
That a large purple streme adown their giambeux falles.
And purple robe gored with many a wound;
That vnderneath his feet soone made a purple plesh.
In a long purple pall, whose skirt with gold,
And the gray Ocean into purple dy:
That drops of purple bloud thereout did weepe,
Sad Amaranthus, in whose purple gore
That all the ground with purple bloud was sprent,
Thence streames of purple bloud issuing rife,
And pour'd the purple bloud forth on the gras;
At length did marke about her purple brest
With nimble wings of gold and purple hew;
All in a Camis light of purple silke
That glauncing downe his thigh, the purple bloud forth drew.
The which she couering with her purple pall
For they were all, they say, of purple hew,
The morrow next appear'd, with purple hayre
And all his armour did with purple dye;
That at the last like to a purple lake
When he beheld the streames of purple blood
She mote perceiue a litle purple mold,
The litle purple rose, which thereon grew,
Diuine Scamander, purpled yet with blood
The cloth of state, and on their purpled wings
(For she her sexe vnder that straunge purport
There written was the purport of his sin,
For other whiles to her she purpos made
And to his purposd iourney him prepar'd:
Vnto that purposd place I did me draw,
He purposd to proceed, what so be fall,
And fitting gestures to her purpose frame;
And for her humour fitting purpose faine,
Nor noyous smell his purpose could withhold,
On which they lowly sit, and fitting purpose frame.
For she was inly glad her purpose so to gaine.
Her purpose was not such, as she did faine,
Me all vnfit for so great purpose she employes.
Then forward he his purpose gan pursew,
And I pursewing my fell purpose, after went.
Yet mildly him to purpose answered;
With cruell purpose bent to wreake on him
For she in pleasant purpose did abound,
So pleased, did his wrathfull purpose faire appease.
But whenas Mammon saw his purpose mist,
So goodly purpose they together fond,
Mote stead you much your purpose to subdew.
Them gan to bord, and purpose diuersly,
Where she for secret purpose did appoynt
Of sundry things faire purpose gan to find,
And to their purpose vsed wicked art:
The fatall purpose of diuine foresight,
And yet was loth to let her purpose plaine appeare.
Way for themselues, their purpose to partake?
And to possesse the purpose they desird:
Both speare & shield of great powre, for her purpose fit.
T'approue the vnknowen purpose of eternall fate.
He gan make gentle purpose to his Dame,
Purpose was moued by that gentle Dame,
With purpose, how they might it best betray;
Till they arriu'd, whereas their purpose they did plot.
That twixt themselues did gentle purpose make
But to small purpose yron wedges made;
From his reuengefull purpose shronke abacke,
And by the way she sundry purpose found
But see how much her purpose was deceaued.
The last daies purpose of their vowed fight,
Of her intent, this further purpose to him shope.
For comming to this knight, she purpose fayned,
He should his purpose misse, which close he ment:
It would no passage yeeld vnto his purpose vaine.
Whom they by slights allur'd, and to their purpose lad.
Somewhile with merry purpose fit to please,
A further purpose, would not so them slay,
Of sundrie things he purpose gan to faine;
With goodly purposes there as they sit:
Of false Pellite, his purposes to breake,
Oft purposes, oft riddles he deuysd,
Their purpost flight, free from all mens reclame;
That famous hard atchieuements still pursew,
With fresh desire his voyage to pursew:
Would not a while her forward course pursew,
Pursew the end of their strong enmity,
Then forward he his purpose gan pursew,
Pursew her steps, through wild vnknowen wood;
Already fought, his voyage to pursew.
From heauens sight, and powre of all which the[m] pursew.
What straunge aduenture do ye now pursew?
That him his foe more fiercely should pursew:
The flying ships with swiftnesse to pursew,
Yet did false Archimage her still pursew,
Those two great cha[m]pions did attonce pursew
Through thicke and thin her to pursew apace,
The fearefull boy so greedily pursew,
The which with speedie pace did after them pursew.
The which for length I will not here pursew,
Whom after did a mightie man pursew,
He fear'd least they with shame would him pursew.
These noble warriors, mindefull to pursew
Which fayling he gan fiercely her pursew.
And eke pursew, if he attaine it may.
So cruelly did him pursew and chace,
But Artegall him after did pursew,
Nathlesse the yron man did still pursew
The Blattant Beast (quoth he) I doe pursew,
Against his foe that did him so pursew:
Securely he did after him pursew,
Him booted not to thinke them to pursew,
Yet he them still so sharpely did pursew,
Himselfe in hast he arm'd, and did him fast pursew.
And now your crime with cruelty pursew.
So sharply he the Monster did pursew,
He left his stond, and her pursewd apace,
As I her, so he me pursewd apace,
But she so fast pursewd, that him she tooke,
As fearing euill, that pursewd her fast;
Her selfe pursewd, in hope to win thereby
For whiles his Lord pursewd that noble Mayd,
She on a day, as she pursewd the chace
Her hard pursewd, and sought for to suppresse;
Yet her the hardy knight pursewd so nye,
From that his cruell foe, that him pursewd in sight.
And me pursew'd; but nathemore would I
His yron page, who him pursew'd so light,
But Artegall pursewd him still so neare,
Yet still the Prince pursew'd him close behind,
He him pursewd, where euer that he went,
So well he him pursew'd, that at the last,
Yet he him still pursew'd from place to place,
And with more eager felnesse him pursew'd:
Nathelesse so sharpely still he him pursewd,
There on a day as he pursew'd the chace,
As all the like, which honour haue pursewed
Whom Guyon seeing stoup, pursewed fast
That her pursewed, saw with great remorse,
Sometimes pursewing, and sometimes pursewed,
Irenaes quest pursewed,
And him pursewed with importune speed,
Yet by the cry he follow'd, and pursewed fast.
Malbecco her pursewes:
And I pursewing my fell purpose, after went.
After pursewing death once to require,
She left, pursewing that same foster strong;
Sometimes pursewing, and sometimes pursewed,
And her pursu'd as fast as she did flie:
But th'other still pursu'd the fearefull Mayd;
And for what cause pursu'd of them attone.
The which with mortall malice him pursu'd so nere.
He fiercely him pursu'd, and pressed sore,
He him pursu'd and chaced through the plaine,
Pursu'd him streight, in mynd to bene ywroken
And them pursu'd into their dortours sad,
Putting his puissaunce forth, pursu'd so hard,
So long they fight, and fell reuenge pursue,
Whom to pursue, the Infant after hide,
Which vauntage Cambell did pursue so fast,
So tempting her still to pursue the pray,
The more did she pursue her lewd intent,
Resolued to pursue his former quest;
So to pursue a perillous emprize,
Which I pursue, of whom I am right glad
For to pursue that villaine, which had reft
And whiles he her pursued euery where,
Pursues the Blatant Beast:
But that bold knight, whom ye pursuing saw
Pursuing that faire Lady full of feare;
So as he was pursuing of his quest
Pursuing him apace with greedy speede,
Pursuing that proud Knight, the which whileare
But he him fast pursuing, soone approched neare.
Whilest Satyrane him from pursuit did let:
And draw them from pursuit of praise and fame,
In braue pursuit of honorable deed,
His wearisome pursuit perforce he stayd,
The Beast with their pursuit incited more,
The flitting skyes, like flying Pursuiuant,
Giue no ods to your foes, but do puruay
It can puruay in twinckling of an eye;
But all things did conueniently puruay:
He all things did puruay, which for them needfull weare.
And powring balme, which he had long puruayd,
Whence mounting vp, they find purueyance meet
And to the ill purueyance of his page,
And rich purueyance might vneath be red;
So rich purueyance, ne them keepe with carefulnesse.
Yet so great was the puissance of his push,
With dint of sword, nor push of pointed speare;
Yet sore amoued with so puissant push,
His tyreling iade he fiercely forth did push,
And with the push of his sharp-pointed speare
Then rudely he him thrust, and pusht with paine,
That one did reach, the other pusht away,
At which Cocytus quakes, and Styx is put to flight.
But now seemde best, the person to put on
Much rueth me; but now put feare apart,
To comfort her, and feare to put away,
His trembling hand he would him force to put
To put away out of his carefull brest.
But with redoubled buffes them backe did put:
Resolu'd to put away that loathly blame,
Stird Porrex vp to put his brother downe;
And pitteous Elidure put in his sted;
And meet respect of honour put to flight:
Tho whenas all were put to shamefull flight,
Of dreadfull things the same was put to flight,
And bad her all things put in readinesse anon.
To scale the skyes, and put Ioue from his right:
How many foundst thou such to put in thy record?
Of life, she put a Spright to rule the carkasse dead.
By their faire handling, put into Malbeccoes cape.
And mickle perill to be put to shame.
He then did put, her pleasures lenger to partake.
And put away remembrance of late teene;
With that he put his spurres vnto his steed,
Did priuily put coles vnto his secret fire.
And in this prison put him here with me:
So first the right he put into one scale;
And put two wrongs together to be tride,
Which some hath put to shame, and many done be dead.
And put to that base seruice of her band,
And put before his lap a napron white,
That all the Temple put in ieopardy
Was raced out, and Mal was now put in.
Whom she did put to death, deceiued like a foole.
To put to sea, with whom they did compound,
But put away proud looke, and vsage sterne,
Fain'd her to frolicke, and to put away
And put them all about himselfe vnfit,
T'amend what was amisse, and put in right aray.
Were vanquished, and put to foule disgrace,
I put the teares of my contrition,
I put repentaunce for things past and gon.
That all which I put in, fals out anon;
And did it put on Coridons in stead:
The inner parts now gan to putrify,
The Damzell streight obayd, and putting all
But putting spurres vnto her fiery beast,
Putting his puissaunce forth, pursu'd so hard,
Like as a Puttocke hauing spyde in sight
Some like to Puttockes, all in plumes arayd:
Like puttocks clawes: with th'one of which she scracht
Dropped with brackish deaw; his three-forkt Pyke
Pylades and Orestes by his syde;
Nor that sage Pylian syre, which did suruiue
The lucky Pylot of her passage sad,
Farre passing Bronteus, or Pynacmon great,
But pynd away in anguish and selfe-wild annoy.
And pyn'd his flesh, to keepe his body low and chast.
But pyn'd, &; mourn'd, & languisht, and alone did weepe.
For want whereof poore people oft did pyne;
But they were forst through penurie and pyne,
She shortly like a pyned ghost became,
And pyning anguish hid in gentle hart,
Which to outbarre, with painefull pyonings
Like as the fouler on his guilefull pype
The which did pype and sing her prayses dew,
Pype iolly shepheard, pype thou now apace
Pype iolly shepheard, pype thou now apace
Tho vp they gan their merry pypes to trusse,
Playing on pypes, and caroling apace,
Where wont the shepheards oft their pypes resound,
Was she to whom that shepheard pypt alone,
He pypt apace, whilest they him daunst about.
Were throwne by Pyrrha and Deucalione:
Pyrrhochles is his name, renowmed farre
Of Amazons, whom Pyrrhus did destroy,
That shall Pyrrochles well requite, I wot,
Pyrrochles does with Guyon fight,
As did Pyrrochles, and it wilfully vnbindes.
Pyrrochles was, and grieued eke entyre;
Fly, O Pyrrochles, fly the dreadfull warre,
Both Guyon and Pyrrochles: th'one (said shee)
That he would algates with Pyrrochles fight,
Now gan Pyrrochles wex as wood, as hee,
Against Pyrrochles, and new matter framed
But rash Pyrrochles varlet, Atin hight,
Whiles sad Pyrrochles lies on senselesse ground,
On him, that did Pyrrochles deare dismay:
He with Pyrrochles sharp debatement made;
His owne deare Lord Pyrrochles, in sad plight,
Pyrrochles, Ã´ Pyrrochles, what is thee betyde?
Pyrrochles, Ã´ Pyrrochles, what is thee betyde?
Ah be it (said he) from Pyrrochles farre
To see Pyrrochles there so rudely rage:
And cald, Pyrrochles, what is this, I see?
Whom when Pyrrochles saw, inflam'd with rage,
But fierce Pyrrochles, lacking his owne sword,
In vaine therefore, Pyrrochles, should I lend
Pyrrochles gan reply the second time,
Now to Pyrrochles many strokes he told;
But euer at Pyrrochles when he smit,
And suffred rash Pyrrochles wast his idle might.
Damon and Pythias whom death could not seuer;
With heauenly seed, whereof wise Pï¿½on sprong)
And twixt them both a quadrate was the base,
Wise Socrates, who thereof quaffing glad
With which she earst tryumphed, now did quail
And furious fits at earst quite weren quaild:
To driue him to despaire, and quite to quaile,
Withouten sword or shield, an host to quaile?
Their strokes did raine, yet did he neuer quaile,
So thinking for to make her stubborne courage quaile.
That so to see him made her heart to quaile:
Yet quaile in conquest of that land of gold.
And rage to quaile, he tooke a muzzell strong
And wearie limbs a while. She nothing quaint
And euerie looke was coy, and wondrous quaint,
At which his vncouth guise and vsage quaint
Of Hecate: whereat he gan to quake,
That of himselfe he oft for feare would quake,
That euery beast for feare of him did fly and quake.
Yet might her pitteous hart be seene to pant and quake.
That stoutest heart, I weene, could cause to quake.
The stedfast globe of earth, as it for feare did quake.
But trembling euery ioynt did inly quake,
Paine, hunger, cold, that makes the hart to quake;
And gaue it him in hand: his hand did quake,
That made the Redcrosse knight nigh quake for feare,
Who feigning then in euery limbe to quake,
At which bold word that boaster gan to quake,
That yet I quake and tremble ouer all.
That seem'd to tremble euermore, and quake:
As if she had a feuer fit, did quake,
Which all that while she felt to pant and quake,
The feends do quake, when any him to them does name.
The warlike Mertians for feare to quake:
Exploits made Rome to quake, stout Guendolen,
Who seem'd for feare to quake in euery lim,
Full dreadfully he shooke that all did quake,
Anon she gan perceiue the house to quake,
And euerie limbe that touched her did quake:
He felt his hart for very paine to quake,
And made ech member quake, and manly hart to quayle.
Then gan her heart to faint, and quake, and earne,
Of his ill newes, did inly chill and quake,
Of slaughtred carkasses, her heart did quake
That whylome wont to doe so many quake,
Did quake to heare, and nigh asunder brast.
Began to quake and tremble with dismay;
Whylest euery ioynt for dread of death did quake,
But still did lie as dead, and quake, and quiuer,
Her heart does quake, and deadly pallid hew
The fearefull Dame all quaked at the sight,
That all the castle quaked from the ground,
Wherewith the stiffe beame quaked, as affrayd,
Which quaked vnder their so hideous masse,
At which Cocytus quakes, and Styx is put to flight.
Which quit from death yet quakes in euery lim
That all the forrest quakes to heare him rore:
With quaking hands, and other signs of feare:
That oftentimes he quakt, and fainted oftentimes.
That in short space he has them qualifyde,
But strifull minde, and diuerse qualitee
With two companions of like qualitie,
Of sundry kindes, and sundry quality;
And shortly grew to so great quantitie,
Discharged of his bow and deadly quar'le,
But to the ground the idle quarrell fell:
In better quarrell, then defence of right,
Perhaps I may all further quarrell end,
Which tooke in hand her quarrell to maintaine;
A wrongfull quarrell to maintaine by fight;
Amongst her louers, and great quarrels wrought,
The stone-dead quarrey fals so forciblie,
The quarrey throwes to ground with fell despight,
Her from the quarrey he away doth driue,
Whilest they together for the quarrey stroue,
And Camber did possesse the Westerne quart,
And thereof nigh one quarter sheard away;
Full measured three quarters of her yeare,
Is not enough foure quarters of a man,
He bore a bloudie Crosse, that quartred all the field.
Quartred athwart, and bearing in his targe
Therewith his sturdie courage soone was quayd,
And all her senses with abashment quite were quayld.
And made ech member quake, and manly hart to quayle.
Regardlesse of that queane so base and vilde,
That greatest Glorious Queene of Faerie lond,
And she her selfe of beautie soueraigne Queene,
A mayden Queene, that shone as Titans ray,
And sad Proserpina the Queene of hell;
That made her selfe a Queene, and crownd to be,
Till that great Queene vpon eternall paine
So be, O Queene, you equall fauour showe.
At last forth comes that far renowmed Queene,
Wherewith he goeth to that soueraine Queene,
Vp then, vp dreary Dame, of darknesse Queene,
For daring tempt the Queene of heauen to sin;
Do worship her, as Queene, with oliue girlond cround.
But when he dyde, the Faerie Queene it brought
